DataElement.preferredName: Invasive Colorectal Carcinoma Tumor Cell Invasion Extent Depth of Tumor Invasion Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The depth of the tumor invasion of the colorectal carcinoma tumor cell.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Invasive Colorectal Carcinoma Tumor Cell Invasion Extent
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Marked by a tendency to spread, especially into healthy surrounding tissue.:Grossly, most colorectal carcinomas are either polypoid or of the ulcerative -infiltrating type.  Adenocarcinoma is the most common carcinoma in the colon and rectum.  Colorectal adenocarcinoma can be divided in three grades: Grade I (low grade or well-di_The local spread of tumor cells of a malignant neoplasm through infiltration or destruction of adjacent tissue; for epithelial neoplasms, invasion signifies infiltration beneath the epithelial basement membrane.:The range, magnitude, or distance over which a thing spans an interval of distance, space, or time.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Marked by a tendency to spread, especially into healthy surrounding tissue.:Grossly, most colorectal carcinomas are either polypoid or of the ulcerative -infiltrating type.  Adenocarcinoma is the most common carcinoma in the colon and rectum.  Colorectal adenocarcinoma can be divided in three grades: Grade I (low grade or well-di

Concepts.definition: Marked by a tendency to spread, especially into healthy surrounding tissue.
A malignant epithelial neoplasm that arises from the colon or rectum and invades through the muscularis mucosa into the submucosa.  The vast majority are adenocarcinomas.

Property.preferredDefinition: The local spread of tumor cells of a malignant neoplasm through infiltration or destruction of adjacent tissue; for epithelial neoplasms, invasion signifies infiltration beneath the epithelial basement membrane.:The range, magnitude, or distance over which a thing spans an interval of distance, space, or time.

Concepts.definition: The local spread of tumor cells of a malignant neoplasm through infiltration or destruction of adjacent tissue; for epithelial neoplasms, invasion signifies infiltration beneath the epithelial basement membrane.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Default Conceptual Domain for UML Loader

ValueDomain.preferredName: Colorectal Neoplasm Depth of Tumor Invasion Type
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant neoplasm that affects the colon or rectum.  Representative examples of benign neoplasms include lipoma and leiomyoma.  Representative examples of malignant neoplasms include carcinoma, lymphoma, and sarcoma.  Colorectal adenomas always exhibit epithelial dysplasia and are considered premalignant neoplasms._An evaluation of the downward or inward extent of tumor invasion into a tissue._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The connective tissue coat of a mucous membrane including the epithelium and basement membrane.

Concepts.definition: The connective tissue coat of a mucous membrane including the epithelium and basement membrane.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A thin layer of smooth muscle fibers found as a part of the tunica mucosa in the gastrointestinal tract and urinary bladder deep to the lamina propria mucosae.

Concepts.definition: A thin layer of smooth muscle fibers found as a part of the tunica mucosa in the gastrointestinal tract and urinary bladder deep to the lamina propria mucosae.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A layer of areolar tissue beneath the mucous membrane

Concepts.definition: A layer of areolar tissue beneath the mucous membrane

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The detrusor muscle of the bladder, forming the muscular wall of the bladder, consisting of the inner longitudinal; middle circular; and outer longitudinal layers.

Concepts.definition: The detrusor muscle of the bladder, forming the muscular wall of the bladder, consisting of the inner longitudinal; middle circular; and outer longitudinal layers.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 10/10/23 changed Long Name from "Not Stated" to match NCIt Preferred name and current caDSR concept Long Name of "Not Reported" per Brenda.Janice . LS

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A membrane lining the external walls of the body cavities and reflected over the surfaces of protruding organs. It consists of mesothelium lying on a connective tissue layer, and secretes a watery exudate.

Concepts.definition: A membrane lining the external walls of the body cavities and reflected over the surfaces of protruding organs. It consists of mesothelium lying on a connective tissue layer, and secretes a watery exudate.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Extending on all sides of simultaneously; encircling._Of or pertaining to the rectum._An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function.

Concepts.definition: Extending on all sides of simultaneously; encircling.
Of or pertaining to the rectum.
An anatomical structure consisting of similarly specialized cells and intercellular matrix, aggregated according to genetically determined spatial relationships, performing a specific function.
